item.title: Freed From Israeli Prisons, Gazans Return to ‘Rubble and Sand’
item.description: Roughly 1,700 Palestinians detained by Israel in the past few years have recently returned to Gaza. Many are trying to reacclimate into a shattered society.
item.dc:creator: Saleh al-Batati

item.title: As Putin Digs In, a Long—and Different—War With Ukraine Looms
item.description: Long-range strikes on infrastructure are becoming increasingly critical as front-line advances stall.
item.dc:creator: Yaroslav Trofimov

item.title: Milei’s Overhaul of Argentina Has Another Problem: He Isn’t Great at Politics
item.description: The libertarian leader has stabilized the economy but lost political allies, run into scandals and is fielding untested candidates.
item.dc:creator: Juan Forero

item.title: How One Ad Sent U.S.-Canada Trade Talks Into a Tailspin
item.description: Negotiators had been working for weeks on a potential agreement to reduce President Trump’s steel and aluminum tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Alex Leary

item.title: Pentagon Orders Aircraft Carrier to the Caribbean
item.description: The move would be a major escalation of the Trump administration’s military campaign to target drug smugglers and threaten governments in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Lara Seligman

item.title: Opinion | Trump Says the Road to Gaza Ran Through Tehran
item.description: The key to the cease-fire was to defeat the Iranian bully first, and the President makes a strong case
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | Britain Nears Its Net-Zero Breaking Point
item.description: Voters are fed up with rising energy costs and politicians are worried.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | Puerto Rico’s Democrats Like Their Commonwealth Status
item.description: Stateside party leaders dream of statehood, but taxes and culture make the status quo preferable.
item.dc:creator: Pablo José Hernández

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Colombia’s President Over Drug-Trafficking Accusations
item.description: The Treasury Department has sanctioned Colombian President Gustavo Petro and his family, alleging his government has aided drug traffickers.
item.dc:creator: Jack Morphet

item.title: The Feisty Ontario Leader Who Torpedoed Negotiations With Trump—Again
item.description: An ad criticizing tariffs was the latest example of Doug Ford’s disruptive role in Canada’s trade talks with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Vipal Monga

item.title: Ontario to Pause Anti-Tariff Ad Campaign After Trump Called Off Trade Talks
item.description: The advertisement, which features a recording of Ronald Reagan, was sharply criticized by the U.S. president.
item.dc:creator: Vipal Monga

item.title: Ontario to Pause Anti-Tariff Commercial After Trump Calls Off Trade Talks
item.description: The advertising campaign, which featured Ronald Reagan speaking negatively about tariffs, will be paused so that negotiations can resume, said Ontario Premier Doug Ford.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Opinion | A Strange ‘Apartheid’ State
item.description: The Jewish state sends the parents of every Arab and Jewish Israeli a monthly check for each of their children up to age 18.

item.title: Trump Says He Is Terminating Trade Negotiations With Canada
item.description: The president criticized Ottawa for an advertisement featuring Ronald Reagan speaking negatively about tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Vipal Monga

item.title: Russia’s Central Bank Cuts Key Rate as New Sanctions Loom
item.description: The cut comes as an already slowing economy braces for the impact of fresh sanctions in response to President Vladimir Putin’s continued war on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Has Argentina Really Changed? Soon, We Will Find Out
item.description: The U.S. is betting $20 billion that with time and support, President Javier Milei can fix Argentina’s economy once and for all.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Saab Lifts Full-Year Sales Guidance as Defense Demand Remains Strong
item.description: The company’s order backlog hit a record high as nations continue to boost their military capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Dominic Chopping

item.title: Full Impact of Tariffs on Asia-Pacific Still to Come, IMF Warns
item.description: Asia-Pacific economies fared better than expected in the first half of the year but the IMF warns that the full blow of U.S. tariff hikes remains unclear, and growth will slow.
item.dc:creator: Fabiana Negrin Ochoa

item.title: Most-Wanted Fentanyl Producer Is Extradited to the U.S. After Brazen Escape
item.description: Zhi Dong Zhang, an accused Chinese drug boss, fled house arrest in Mexico, traveled to Cuba and was denied entry by Russia.
item.dc:creator: José de Córdoba

item.title: Hamas Has Calculated It Can Survive in Gaza—and Rule
item.description: The group is betting it can assert itself without triggering a return to war, but the president’s plan calls for the militants’ capitulation.
item.dc:creator: Summer Said

item.title: Will India and China Be Able to Resist U.S. Sanctions on Russian Oil?
item.description: New Delhi and Beijing have so far resisted U.S. calls to stop buying Russian crude, but far-reaching sanctions will be hard to ignore.
item.dc:creator: Jiahui Huang

item.title: Military Tech Companies, Long Snubbed in Europe, Are Having a Moment
item.description: Russia’s aggression and Trump’s re-election have prompted Europe’s startup scene to tackle defense, drawing U.S. investors.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Michaels

item.title: China’s New Strategy for Trump: Punch Hard, Concede Little
item.description: For Xi, rare-earths bombshell signaled a new toughness, while TikTok was ‘spiritual opium’ that could be turned into a low-cost bargaining chip.
item.dc:creator: Lingling Wei

item.title: Why Trump Reached a Breaking Point With Putin
item.description: The U.S. president was given three options for sanctions after running out of patience with the Kremlin over its war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Ward

item.title: U.S. Sends B-1 Bombers Near Venezuela, Ramping Up Military Pressure
item.description: The flights signal a possible widening of the U.S. campaign against cartels and alleged drug traffickers.
item.dc:creator: Lara Seligman

item.title: Opinion | Saudis Just Want to Have Fun
item.description: Events like the Riyadh Comedy Festival aren’t about whitewashing the kingdom’s human-rights record.
item.dc:creator: Michael Ratney

item.title: Opinion | Putting the Oil Squeeze on Putin
item.description: Strong world crude supply gives Trump room to tighten—and enforce—sanctions.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: U.S. Set to Examine China’s Compliance With 2020 Trade Deal
item.description: The move reopens an old trade dispute ahead of Trump’s meeting with China’s Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Bade

item.title: U.S. Oil Sanctions Strike at Russia’s Economic Lifeline
item.description: The U.S. has hit Moscow’s biggest oil producers at a vulnerable time for the country’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Laurence Norman

item.title: Vance Rebukes ‘Stupid’ Vote in Israel to Annex the West Bank
item.description: The comments, in response to a largely symbolic measure, came at a key juncture for President Trump’s Gaza peace plan.
item.dc:creator: Dov Lieber

item.title: Why North Korea Has Scaled Back Its Missile Tests This Year
item.description: On the heels of major advances, Pyongyang is shifting away from seeking attention with a flurry of launches and focusing on solidifying its nuclear status.
item.dc:creator: Dasl Yoon

item.title: China Gears Up for More Tech Confrontation With U.S.
item.description: China will seek to become more self-sufficient technologically over the coming five years, the ruling Communist Party said in a new economic blueprint.
item.dc:creator: Yoko Kubota

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Purges Shrink Ranks of China’s Communist Elite—and Boost His Power
item.description: Nearly one in six officials who had Central Committee seats were absent from a major conclave, many of them now disgraced.
item.dc:creator: Chun Han Wong

item.title: U.S. Imposes Substantial New Sanctions on Russian Oil Giants
item.description: The measures against Lukoil and Rosneft come as negotiations over ending the war in Ukraine have stalled.
item.dc:creator: Laurence Norman

item.title: U.S. Widens Campaign Against Alleged Drug Boats With Eastern Pacific Strikes
item.description: Five people were killed in the attacks as the military targeted suspected trafficking in an area where large amounts of cocaine typically move.
item.dc:creator: Juan Forero

item.title: A Parade of Senior U.S. Officials Descends on Israel for ‘Bibisitting’ Duty
item.description: Trump has touted Gaza cease-fire as the “historic dawn of a new Middle East,” but the old Middle East isn’t entirely gone.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Ward

item.title: Bank of Korea Holds Rate Steady for Third Straight Time
item.description: South Korea’s central bank held its policy rate steady, reflecting caution over financial-stability risks and uncertainty over tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: Islamic State Rises Again in Syria, Filling a Void Left by U.S.
item.description: Attacks by the militant group are up as it exploits a reduced American presence and the collapse of the Assad regime. “They have returned to our city.”
item.dc:creator: Sudarsan Raghavan

item.title: Trump’s ‘Donroe Doctrine’ Aims to Dominate the Americas
item.description: From attacking drug boats to pressuring Venezuela’s leader, the President is putting the Western Hemisphere at the center of his foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: Vera Bergengruen

item.title: U.S. Lifts Key Restriction on Ukraine’s Use of European Long-Range Missiles
item.description: The move coincides with a Trump push to pressure Moscow into talks on ending the war and to withhold U.S. Tomahawk missiles from Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Ward

item.title: Surveillance Camera Pointed the Wrong Way Allowed Louvre Heist
item.description: Officials say an outdated surveillance system left the world-famous museum in Paris vulnerable despite years of warnings.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Meichtry

item.title: U.N. Court Says Israel Must Allow Unrwa Aid Into Gaza
item.description: The United Nations sought an advisory opinion on the obligations of member states, but stability of the U.S.-brokered cease-fire is a bigger issue now.
item.dc:creator: James Hookway

item.title: A U.S. Plan Splits Gaza in Two—One Zone Controlled by Israel, One by Hamas
item.description: The U.S. and Israel are considering a plan that would divide Gaza into separate zones controlled by Israel and Hamas, with reconstruction only taking place on the Israeli side.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Ward

item.title: U.K. Inflation Unexpectedly Holds Steady
item.description: The country’s annual rate of inflation in September was at the same pace seen in August, but was still well above the Bank of England’s target.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Japan’s Exports Rebound From Months of Decline, But Tariff Risks Remain
item.description: Outbound shipments rose 4.2% from a year earlier last month, bouncing back from August’s 0.1% decline, finance ministry data showed.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Trump Says Ukraine Summit With Putin Would Be a ‘Waste of Time’
item.description: The administration has concluded that Russia is clinging to territorial ambitions that make a peace deal with Ukraine impossible.
item.dc:creator: Alex Leary

item.title: Corruption Scandals Bring Trouble for Nelson Mandela’s Party
item.description: Critics say African National Congress members enrich themselves and their friends using laws meant to empower South Africa’s Black majority.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Are No Closer to Cease-Fire After Trump’s Pressure on Zelensky
item.description: U.S. president wants a swift end to the conflict, but both sides are digging in over the region in Ukraine’s east.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Ward

item.title: Trump Signals Support for Selling Submarines to Australia
item.description: The president’s comments calmed fears that he would pull out of the Biden-era deal and came as he struck an agreement with the U.S. ally on rare earths.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: U.K. Government Overshoots Borrowing Target in First Half, Making Tax Rises Likely
item.description: A key goal for the government, according to economists, should be to persuade investors the government has the will and policies to whittle down debt over coming years.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: How a Right-Wing Hindu Group Went From Fringe to Mainstream in India
item.description: India’s Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh group is stepping out of the shadows and flexing its power.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Brazen Heist at Louvre Museum Snatches Priceless Royal Jewels
item.description: Thieves used a truck-mounted furniture elevator to reach the gallery housing the artifacts at the Paris museum and then fled on motorcycles, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Sam Schechner

item.title: Cargo Plane Accident Kills Two in Hong Kong
item.description: The accident involved a Boeing 747-400 cargo aircraft that had departed from Dubai’s Al Maktoum International Airport.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Cheng

item.title: Prince Andrew Loses ‘Duke of York’ Title After Epstein Scandal
item.description: The prince agrees to forgo use of his royal title after pressure from Buckingham Palace.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: Trump Organization Expands in India, Where Many of Its Partners Face Accusations
item.description: Indian real-estate firms have been accused of fraud, money laundering and more on other projects. The Trumps have stepped up overseas deals in the president’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Peter Grant

item.title: India Delicately Counters Trump Claim It Will Drop Russian Oil
item.description: New Delhi didn’t outright contradict the president, saying it was committed to protecting consumers by diversifying its energy supplies.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: The Chinese Spy Scandal That Is Rocking Britain’s Government
item.description: When a British parliamentary researcher was arrested for allegedly spying for China, security officials expected a slam-dunk case. Instead, the trial collapsed.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: Microsoft, Anthropic Hire Former British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak
item.description: Sunak, who remains a member of Britain’s parliament, said he would be working with the tech companies as a senior adviser and strategic consultant.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Look

item.title: International Criminal Court Convicts Sudanese Militia Leader of War Crimes
item.description: The guilty finding is a rare conviction for the court, and comes as the institution confronts U.S. sanctions and sexual-assault allegations.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Dalton

item.title: German Firm’s African Green-Energy Project Runs Into Ghosts From Past
item.description: Namibia’s indigenous Nama population argues they have been sidelined in a $10 billion project being built on their ancestral lands.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Kimeu

item.title: Powerful Earthquake Kills at Least 69 People in Central Philippines
item.description: The Philippines sits in the so-called Ring of Fire, a seismic arc of volcanoes and fault lines around the Pacific basin.
item.dc:creator: Gabriele Steinhauser

item.title: Russia’s Ambitious Plans in Africa Are Unraveling
item.description: Not long ago a rising military force in Africa, Russia is now struggling to maintain its footprint on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: The Path to the American Dream Is Narrowing for Indian Tech Workers
item.description: About 70% of H-1B visas go to Indians. Looming changes to the program are upending plans, but may help India retain talent.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: The Race Back to America for a Plane Full of H-1B Workers
item.description: Reports of a new visa fee for foreign workers prompted hasty goodbyes, races to the airport and an anxiety-filled flight to San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: Robert McMillan

item.title: Pentagon Review of Aukus Security Pact Worries U.K., Australia
item.description: The review throws into doubt a strategic partnership that aims to give Australia nuclear-powered submarines and deter Chinese aggression in the Indo-Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Rhiannon Hoyle

item.title: The Best Travel Shoes to Make Every Trip Lighter and Easier
item.description: No matter the destination, these shoes will get you there.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Selinger

item.title: The Best Laptop Backpacks, According to CEOs, Pilots and Stylists
item.description: From commuting to long-haul flights, these are the bags avid travelers rely on for their trips.
item.dc:creator: Sal Vaglica

item.title: Best of Buy Side Awards 2025: Travel
item.description: Tried and tested by our expert travel writers and editors, these Buy Side best product award-winning luggage picks will ensure your trip gets off to a great start.
item.dc:creator: Nick Guy

item.title: Russia’s Side Quest to Dominate Africa: Hijack a Videogame
item.description: Players in the ‘African Dawn’ videogame are asked to choose a side aligned with either Russia or the West.
item.dc:creator: Sarah E. Needleman

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: ‘We’ve Got to Kill’: Inside New Zealand’s Mission to Wipe Out Predators
item.description: Scientists debate whether a multibillion-dollar plan to eliminate invasive animals by 2050 is feasible.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney
